comments:
When performing a drag and drop . Eclipse deletes the file and then copies the 
file. This is causing a problem in the harvest plugin. 
Instead it should overwrite over the existing file. When a file is checked into 
harvest. The file has a decorator on it ,indicating the file is checked into 
harvest. Checkout a file and perfrom the drag and drop operation. When a file 
is checked out. The decorator changes to a check mark. During a drag and drop. 
The file is deleted and then copied. When a delete is performed .Harvest 
intercepts the delete and unregisters the file. 
When the file is copied over . It has  a new decorator indicated that the file 
is not under harvest control. This is wrong. The file is checked out from 
harvest. If the file is not checked out. The drag and drop operation will fail.

Note: Deletion and replacing the file is also occuring when generation helper 
classes from WSAD 5.0 . This also happens when deploying EJB.
This may be a Core issue?

Any idea as to which version of Eclipse will this issue be fixed. Can we have 
an ETA

At the file system level Eclipse will actually call File.renameTo() for most 
move operations.

The resulting Resource Delta will report that it was not a copy delete only 
but a MOVE.  

You can query this information form an IResourceDelta via:

public IPath getMovedFromPath();
public IPath getMovedToPath();

OR Team providers are given the opportunity to handle the move operation 
themselves, to see how this works have a look at: 

org.eclipse.core.resources.team.IMoveDeleteHook

You can also spy on the resulting deltas from the drag and drop using some 
tools made available by the Core team currently located at: 

http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-core-
home/downloads/tools/org.eclipse.core.tools_1.0.2.zip

Marking as WorksForMe, please re-open if the above information does not answer 
the question.

We have implemented the 
org.eclipse.core.resources.team.IMoveDeleteHook

Can you please provide more details.

Thanks
Usha

As indicated earlier we have implemented the 
org.eclipse.core.resources.team.IMoveDeleteHook

During the drag and drop operation. The file is deleted and then readded.
During the drag and drop ,The deletefile method gets called. In this method. I 
dont see a way of finding out that this operation is not a delete but a drag 
and drop. Note:Also that this is causing a major problem for us for all the 
file replace operations not just limiting to drag and drop.
I would really appreciate your response to this.
Thanks
Usha

From the README which is linked in comment #14 above:

Installing Core Tools

2. If you are running an Eclipse build from before I20021127 (this includes
2.0.*) you will need to get the patched versions of the boot, runtime and
resources plugins. Get core-tools-patches.zip and extract all files into your
<eclipse install>/plugins directory. This will overwrite boot.jar, runtime.jar
and resources.jar. Note that if your install has version numbers in the plug-in
directory names, you have to manually copy/extract the patch files into the
corresponding versioned plug-in directory in your install.

I have extracted the coretools_patches1.0.1.zip to the plugins directory.On 
extracting this zip file. It did not overwrite any files. Instead i have 3 new 
folders 
org.eclipse.core.boot,org.eclipse.core.resources,org.eclipse.core.runtime 
under my plugins directory. Where do i need to copy the patch files 
(core,runtime,resources to ?)

Note that if your install has version numbers in the plug-in directory names,
you have to manually copy/extract the patch files into the corresponding
versioned plug-in directory in your install.

For instance the files in the org.eclipse.core.boot directory should be copied
into the org.eclipse.core.boot_<id> (org.eclipse.core.boot_2.0.2?) directory.

Thanks.

The key part of your steps is that you are "dragging and dropping" from Windows
Explorer into Eclipse.

If you have files and folders within an Eclipse project and you drag and drop
within your workspace (using the Navigator or Packages views) then Eclipse will
detect that the action is a move and behave appropriately. (try my steps in
comment #24 and look at the output in the Delta Spy view)

What you are doing is replacing the contents of a java file which lives in
Eclipse, with contents from a completely random file which Eclipse knows nothing
about. 

A "move" action has two things...a "source" and a "destination". In your case
the "destination" is within Eclipse ("/Testeclipse/A.java") but the "source" is
not ("d:/temp/A.java"). Therefore Eclipse cannot detect this as a "move". It is
really a "replace" action on the resource in your workspace.
Then how do we resolve this ?

What is your code trying to accomplish? Perhaps requiring a "move" is down the
wrong path.

Our code is not expecting a move ,We expect the file not be deleted and then 
replaced but just replaced over the existing file. The delete is what is 
causing a problem for us.

I have verified that this behaviour has changed in Eclipse 2.1.2 (and perhaps in
earlier builds as well) and #setContents is being called rather than #delete and
#create (at the Core level).

I would recommend upgrading your version of Eclipse.
